Review 2D materials modulating layered double hydroxides for electrocatalytic water splitting Jinling Cheng Dingsheng Wang * Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Department of Chemistry Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China * Corresponding author Exploring highly efficient electrochemical water splitting catalysts has recently attracted extensive research interest from both fundamental researches and practical applications. Transition metal-based layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have been proved to be one of the most efficient materials for oxygen evolution reaction (OER), however, still suffered from low conductivity and sluggish kinetics for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which largely inhibited the overall water splitting efficiency. To address this dilemma, enormous approaches including doping regulation, intercalation tuning and defect engineering are therefore rationally designed and developed. Herein, we focus on the recent exciting progress of LDHs hybridization with other two-dimensional (2D) materials for water splitting reactions, not barely for enhancing OER efficiency but also for boosting HER activity. Particularly, the structural features, morphologies, charge transfer and synergistic effects for the heterostructure/heterointerface that influence the electrocatalytic performance are discussed in details. The hybrid 2D building blocks not only serve as additional conductivity and structural supported but also promote electron transfer at the interfaces and further enhance the electrocatalytic performance. The construction and application of the nanohybrid materials will guide a new direction in developing multifunctional materials based on LDHs, which will contribute to energy conversion and storage. Graphical abstract Different classes of 2D materials including 2D carbon based materials, layered transition metal dichalcogenides, transition metal carbides and 2D perovskite oxides regulate transition metal-based layered double hydroxides (LDHs) for electrocatalytic overall water splitting performance. Keywords Layered double hydroxide 2D materials Hybridization Synergistic effect Electrocatalytic water splitting 1 Introduction Catalysis plays a key role in both chemical research and related industrial activities. Climate change, environmental deterioration and energy security have stimulated comprehensive searching for clean and renewable energy sources. For energy-related applications, direct splitting water into H2 and O2 through electrocatalysis has attracted significant attention for producing clean and renewable hydrogen and further accelerating the development of low-carbon economies [1,2]. Electrocatalytic overall water splitting is consisted of two half-cell reactions: producing gaseous hydrogen via HER at the cathode side and oxygen molecules via oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode side [3,4]. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) process involves a two-electron transfer, whereas OER process involves four electrons and four protons transformation which is considered to be the rate-limiting step for the entire water splitting process. The water splitting process can be presented as shown below: Total reaction: H2O → H2 + 1/2O2 In acidic medium: Cathode reaction: 2H+ + 2e – → H2 Anode reaction: H2O → 2H+ + 1/2O2 In alkaline medium: Cathode reaction: 2H2O + 2e – → H2 + 2OH – Anode reaction: 2OH – → H2O + 2e – + 1/2O2 The OER performance traditionally relies heavily on the Ir/Ru based materials, while platinum group metals based materials (Pd, Pt) present most efficient production for HER [3,5–10]. Recent intensive research efforts have been dedicated to explore less precious and more abundant electrocatalysts for water splitting since these noble metals (Pt/Ir/Ru) are economically unbeneficial. In partially, investigations into non-noble metals like Mn, Co, Ni, Fe-containing oxides [11–15], hydroxides [16,17], phosphate [18], spinels [19–21] and perovskites [22,23] for OER have drawn great attention because of their remarkable capability and low cost. Similarly, transition metal based sulfides [24–26], carbides [27,28] and phosphides [29,30] are considered as robust catalysts for HER activity. Ideally, catalysts for both OER and HER reactions could conduct in the same pH medium, in either acidic or basic solution, simplify the overall water electrolyser design, which are highly desired but remains great challenges. Therefore, integrating the virtues of both HER and OER electrocatalysts to conduct bifunctional HER-OER activity with enhanced efficiency and stability that is of beneficial for the enhancement of overall water splitting activity [31–34]. Inspired by the discovery of graphene in 2004 [35], 2D materials, such as graphitic carbon nitride (CNx), transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD), transition-metal oxides (TMOs), hydroxides (TMHs) and MXenes, have emerged in various research fields [36–38]. In particular, 2D materials have opened a new horizon for electrochemical energy conversion/storage applications owing to their unique structure and electronic/electrochemical characteristics. Among varieties of materials, NiFe-layered double hydroxides (NiFe-LDH) present most outstanding OER performance as a kind of potential noble metal-free electrocatalyst in basic solutions with small Tafel slopes and relatively low over potentials [16,39–41]. While, the application of unitary LDHs for the HER is scarcely reported as well as water splitting reactions Therefore, the heterostructures compositing with LDH catalysts and other 2D materials, which not only inherit the inherent superior electronic properties of both materials but also produce novel catalytic performance beyond expectation. To date, many 2D heterostructures based on LDH materials and other nanosheets have been reported. For instance, Yao's group designed and synthesized a bifunctional material based on the integration of NiFe based LDH and defective graphene (DG), the interfaced material has been verified to achieve enhanced electrocatalytic performance for overall water splitting. The heterostructured composites were driven by electrostatic stacking of positively charged LDH and negatively charged DG together [42]. The hybridization has exhibited enhanced electrocatalytic performance for OER in an alkaline solution and outstanding HER activity in the same media as the excellent performance was attributed to the synergetic effects between transition metals and defective carbons. This strongly coupled material is expected to shed light on facilitating wise hybridization between LDHs and other 2D materials for bifunctional applications. On the other hand, one of the insurmountable challenges facing LDHs application is their strong tendency to self-restack which might give rise to extensive loss of the surface area as well as electroactive sites. The self-restacking process is mainly induced by inter-sheets van der Waals forces or hydrogen bonding, in this regard, other sheet materials hybrid with LDHs can isolate the materials from self-stacking, thereby maintaining their textile properties and abundant active sites. Herein, we summarize recent developments in the hybridization between LDHs and other 2D materials for water splitting activities with a focus on their design, synthesis, characterizations, activities and stabilities as illustrated in Scheme 1 . This review will mainly focus on the discussion of the energy application of HER/OER bifunctional overall water splitting beyond OER activity with hybrid LDHs since many reviews have been centralized on the enhancement of OER performance on LDHs including modulating compositions of LDH nanosheets, coordination environment on LDH and hybridization with other materials [16,17,40]. Notably, the heterostructured composites of LDHs are being accepted as one of the most potential bifunctional electrocatalyst that can drive both HER and OER in the same electrolyte, which is crucial in lowering activation energy barrier and accelerating the reaction kinetics for the process of overall water splitting. The review is concluded by offering a short perspective for the design and modulation of the LDHs hybrid materials in electrocatalytic water splitting and the challenges faced by practical application. 2 Characterization and electrocatalytic application of LDH materials Inspired by graphene, ultrathin sheet materials with two 2D morphology have exhibited outstanding properties that are significantly distinct from their bulk counterparts in the fields of physics, chemistry and materials science. LDHs, with a general formula of [M2+ 1–x M3+ x(OH)2] x+·[A n– x/n ] x– mH2O (M commonly represents metal cations like Mg, Fe, Al, Co and A represents interlayer anions such as NO3 – , CO3 2– ), are a family of brucite-type hydroxide sheets. The layered structure is comprised of host metal layers which is positively charged and interlayer anions which is commonly used for charge balance as illustrated in Scheme 2 . The first LDH was discovered in a Norwegian geological specimen by Carl C. F. Hochstetter, a German-Austrian chemist, in 1842 (freely in nature) and its chemical composition was thereafter identified as [Mg0.75Al0.25(OH)2][CO3]0.125 (Mg3Al-CO3-LDH) [43]. Afterwards, an increasing interest has been focused in this fields as various methods has been developed to modulate the synthesis, modification and application of LDHs. The host layer consists of divalent (Ni2+, Co2+, Fe2+, Mg2+, or Zn2+) or trivalent metal (Al3+, Fe3+, Mn3+or Cr3+) cations between hydroxyl and anionic (NO3 – , Cl – , CO3 2– , SO4 2– , and some organic ions) slabs [44,45]. LDHs forming at the mineral-water interface as a hydrogen bonding network is thus built among water molecules (mH2O), interlayer anions (A) and hydroxyl groups (OH – ) in the gallery spaces (Scheme 2). Thus, these structural characteristics facilitate LDHs as a kind of materials with precise design as the chemical composition can be manipulate as (1) The host Brucite-like layer is exchangeable with different kind of divalent M2+ and trivalent M3+ ions with similar ionic radii, or to partly substitute the M2+ and M3+ ions with monovalent (M+) and tetravalent (M4+) ions, such as Li+, K+ and Ti4+, Zr4+. (2) An negative anion interlayer can be exchanged, introducing a variety of inorganic anions (CO3 2– , SO4 2– ), organic anions (OAc – ), complex anions (F6Si2– ) or polyoxometalates(WO3 – ). (3) The layered structure can benefit exfoliation of LDH nanosheets into a monolayer facilitating a promising process to modulating the coordination environment for active sites [46]. The above discussed characteristics of LDHs promote a great flexibility when designing high-performance in a variety of applications like environmental protection [47], energy conversation and storage [48–50], catalysis [51,52], food science and biomaterial [53,54]. Among the aforementioned catalysts, NiFe-LDHs show an extraordinary inherent OER catalytic performance over other binary LDHs based NiAl, CoFe, NiMn, etc [16,55,56]. In NiFe-LDHs, Fe works like “solute” corporately into α-Ni(OH)2/γ-NiOOH lattices, in addition, both Ni and Fe metal sites are potentially responsible for the OER activity [57,57,58]. Notwithstanding these advances, however, it is still a challenge to realize the effective HER performance over NiFe-LDHs unless modified with noble metals like Pt or Pd. Hence, the fine control of LDH hybridization with specific materials to achieve collaborative function is of great viable but still remains a challenge towards extraordinarily bifunctional activities. With the aim of approaching this goal, numbers of ingenious designed systems have been developed based on hybridization of LDHs and other materials. The 2D NiFe-LDH is considered as one of the most potential water splitting electrocatalytic materials as its high OER activity which has been summarized previously by Duan et al. [16]. Whereas, various LDHs catalysts show rather inferior ability toward the HER in alkaline medium due to its deficient electrical conductivity and inadequate active sites for HER process, resulting in a much higher overpotential either sluggish water dissociation kinetics [59,60]. Therefore, much efforts have been made to improve their OER performance as well as the HER activity to realize overall water splitting performance [57,58]. Recently, two major strategies have been proposed to accelerate the HER performance for LDHs. One strategy is to increase the active sites via doping other metal like Ru, Ir or V. For instance, Feng and coworkers developed a novel strategy by doping Ru into NiFe-LDH nanosheet which efficiently reduced energy barrier of the Volmer step, consequently, the obtained NiFeRu-LDH exhibit excellent HER performance [59]. Another strategy is focus on surface emerging to composite hybrid nanomaterials to enhance the surface active sites and electrical conductivity of NiFe-LDH. For example, Jin's group constructed a heterostructure via MoS2 combined with 2D NiFe LDH nanosheets, the hybridization exhibited enhanced surface area and electronic conductivity, which delivering a much lower overpotential of 78 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER [61]. Notwithstanding that extensive effort has been devoted to manipulate the physical and chemical properties for LDH-based material, the overall catalytic efficiency and durability of LDH material-based electrodes for HER and overall water splitting is still far from desired. It is, therefore, crucial to design a more facile strategy to activate the HER efficiency as well as overall water splitting activity of LDHs. 3 Design and construction of the hybridization As aforementioned, the heterostructured materials not only inherit the essential characters of both individual constructions but also promote many updated properties ascribing to the unique heterointerfaces associated with the synergetic effects of two materials. Until now, many 2D heterostructures based on ultrathin LDHs have been designed, synthesized and examined for electrocatalytic water splitting reactions, such as LDH with 2D carbon sheets, transition metal-based oxides and nitride etc. The following sections will give a detailed discussion on their constructions, characterizations and the corresponding water splitting performance. 3.1 In situ formation of secondary materials on LDHs The methodology to build the hybrids via reactive chemical formation of the other material onto the surface of LDH allow for the incorporation of a wide range material compositions. In this regard, LDH nanosheets can be recognized as substrates and a secondary material is able to grow onto the surface. Typical synthetic methods include hydro/solvothermal synthesis, solution processing, or co-precipitation. Although these methods are widely applied in construct bulk materials, heterogeneous interface can be achieved by inducing suitable substrates. This synthesis method provides us with a simple and scalable approach to manufacture many different kinds of hybridization based on LDHs with various morphologies by carefully tailoring the processing conditions. Yu et al. [64] prepared 1T-MoSe2-Se@MgAl-LDH hybridization through an in situ hydrothermal reduction method as illustrated in Fig. 1 . The small space of hydrotalcite layers (0.67–0.75 nm) facilitate the precipitated 2D MoSe2 materials to be thin layer or even single layer. Compared with 1T-MoSe2 nanosheet, the introduction of LDHs endows the hybrid with prominent HER performance, as a small overpotential, Tafel slope as well as remarkable stability are demonstrated. Very recently, Chen and co-workers applied the same method to produce the hybridization of trimetallic NiFeCr-LDH/MoS2 composites by the restriction of hydrotalcite nanosheets [62]. NiFeCr-LDH was firstly prepared via co-precipitation with thiourea, subsequently, the MoO4 2– was added and reacted with S and hydrazine hydrate to generate MoS2 nanosheet attributing to the interlayer confinement of NiFeCr-LDH. The HRTEM diagram suggested uniformly distribution of MoS2 sheet on LDH sheet as the diameter of MoS2 was between 40 and 80 nm. It is worth noting that 1T MoS2 sheet cannot be directly obtained via traditional hydrothermal method, which revealed that the essential role of the confinement effect of LDH layers. Beside 2D TMSs materials, 2D MOFs hybridization can also be produced on top of the LDH substrate. Chen et al. developed a well-designed sublimation-vapor phase pseudomorphic transformation (SVPT) approach to fabricate LDH-templated 2D MOFs [63]. The MOF sheet vertically aligned on the sheet of NiFe-LDH with a uniform and controlled thickness while horizontal placement resulted in unsatisfactory products. The in situ SVPT of LDH@MOF hybrids mainly constructed by two steps. Firstly, the precursor NiFe-LDH nanosheet arrays gradually converted to NiO and NiFe2O4 nanosheet arrays (NiFeO nanosheets) as the temperature raised to 350 °C. Secondly, as the temperature raised to the sublimation point (350 °C) of p-phthalic acid (PTA), the PTA gas phases is obtained gradually and grew on LDH template. By further optimizing the mass of PTA and time, PTA sheet with thickness around 13 nm topologically transformed to LDH-MOF nanosheets. 3.2 In situ formation of LDHs on the other 2D material Compared with in situ grow anther type of 2D material onto LDH material, this method allows for the incorporation of more abundant 2D compositions, independent of the LDH surface identity. Herein, another nanosheets with specific function like graphene, transient metal oxide, Mxene, etc. can be considered as substrates for LDH to grow on as indicated in Fig. 2 . With this methodology, it is possible to modulate the morphology of LDH, the amount of obtained LDH to form hybrids can also be precisely controlled, therefor, the cooperation effect can be regulated by varying the ratio of LDH and another material. As illustrated in Fig. 2(a), CoMn-LDH@ Graphitic C3N4 hybrids by a facile in situ coprecipitation of Mn3+ and Co2+ cations on g-C3N4 sheets was prepared at room temperature [65]. The TEM image indicated that the g-C3N4 nanosheets were well-dispersed in the CoMn-LDH nanosheets, which benefited the ion transportation within nanoscale dimension, thus accelerating the charge transfer for advanced electrocatalytic activity. The investigation of the nature on the charge transfer between the interface of CoMn-LDH and g-C3N4 surface state and chemical bonding was achieved by XPS studies, in which existence of extra C–O, C=O, O–C=O, and Co–N bonds was determined. These results indicated a strong electronic interaction between CoMn-LDH and g-C3N4 not only for chemical structure but also for electronic structures. The hybridization combined the virtue of both materials, thus an efficient bifunctional electrocatalyst and photoelectocatalyst for OER and HER was presented. Moreover, Qiu's group [66,68] reported a FeNi-LDH@Ti3C2T x hybrid material by the co-precipitation of Fe3+ and Ni2+ cations onto Ti3C2T x sheets. The Ti3C2T x nanosheets as indicated in Fig. 2(b) were firstly negatively charged via selectively etching out the Al layers of Ti3AlC2 with strong LiF or HCl solution, leading to abundant OH – and F – ionic group located on top of the Ti3C2 sheet, where Fe3+ and Ni2+ was co-precipitated by addition of urea. The SEM and HRTEM images revealed the construction of FeNi-LDH nanoplate vertically align on top of Ti3C2-MXene. The d-bond center position for Ni and Fe atoms was shifted to higher energy to –2.63 eV as compared to standalone FeNi-LDH sheet (–2.76 eV) further confirmed the synergistic electronic coupling at the interface as indicated in Fig. 2(b). These results indicated that hybridstructure promote FeNi-LDH sheet with enhancing the O binding strength and thus OER activity. Beside of in situ co-precipitation of metal cation to form LDH onto a 2D surfaces, in situ distorting from other formation is of practice. For instance, Zou and co-authors [67] developed a NiCo-LDH@Ti3C2T x material via a MOF distorting approach. After etching and exfoliation, the obtained Ti3C2T x nanosheets were applied as a matrix for the in situ growth of ZIF-67. Afterward, Co2+/Co3+ would be released as ZIF-67 was etched by Ni2+ ions and co-precipitate together to form NiCo-LDH (Fig. 2(c)), as NiCo-LDH@Ti3C2T x was constructed. The TEM image clearly demonstrated that NiCoS sheets was strongly anchored on the 2D Ti3C2T x nanosheets, in addition, the hybrid material was endowed of inherent continuous macropores as large as 70 nm and mesopores as large as 3 nm. Such hierarchical porosity could endow hybrid structure with high surface area and pore volume, which further provided sufficient active sites for electrocatalytic activity and was favorable for electrolyte diffusion and accessibility thus improving the catalytic performance. 3.3 Assembly of secondary 2D material and LDHs Undoubtedly, nonactive assemble is the most universal method to fabricate 2D/2D hybrids. This method generally depends on electrostatic/van der Waals self-assembly principle i.e., cationic LDH and the other anionic 2D building block. Carbon based materials like graphene (DG, GO and rGO), g-C3N4 and carbon nanotubes are potential candidate for the assembly of LDH@Carbon hybrids as g-C3N4, GO, and rGO are facile electrostatically adsorbed onto LDH nanosheets [69]. Generally, the 2D building blockers can not only serve as additional conductivity and structural support but also promote electron transfer at the interfaces and further enhance the electrocatalytic performance. Other 2D materials such as TMDs and MXene can also intercalate with LDH in the same method. Xiong and co-workers [70] developed NiFe-LDH@MoS2, NiFe-LDH@graphene, as well as MoS2@graphene via a solution-phase assembly of the corresponding two types of nanosheets. Notably, the hybrids were assembled by electrostatically attraction, as two oppositely charged unilamellar nanosheets assembled into a superlattice-like structure as described in Fig. 3 . The assemble of positively charged LDH and negatively charged MoS2 exhibited the strongest interaction between the hybrid adjacent layers among these hybrid materials. As an extensive charge distribution as a form of electron accumulation between the interface is confirmed by Bader charge analysis. In addition, the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern suggested that the obtained MoS2@LDH displayed basal spacing of 0.85–0.95 nm, which is comparable to half of the sum of thicknesses of MoS2 and LDH nanosheets (1 nm for each sheet material) as measured by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), which further confirmed the monolayer geometry. Besides the above mentioned conventional approaches, a variety of synthetic methods can also be employed to constitute LDH hybrid nanostructures such as atomic layer deposition (ALD) [73,74], photodeposition or electrodeposition and et al. [75,76] and chemical vapor deposition (CVD) methods [71,77,78]. For example, Li and co-workers [71] have fabricated a hierarchical hollow (Co,Ni)Se2@NiFe LDH nanocage dived by MOF via CVD and thermal strategy. The process via a first two-step selenide construction and then the formation of NiFe LDH material on the surface of (Co,Ni)Se2 [71]. Very recently, a two-step electrodeposition approach was implemented for fabricating Co4S3@NiCo-LDH nanosheet arrays as electrocatalyst for HER. The HRTEM image in Fig. 4(b) demonstrated lattice defects and distortions along the interface of Co4S3 and NiCo-LDH, which indicating that the electrodeposited Co4S3 nanocrystals could introduce as additional sites [72]. 4 2D materials hybrid LDHs for water splitting 4.1 Compositing LDHs with carbon nanomaterials for the water splitting In recent investigations, a variety of carbon-based 2D nanomaterials, such as graphene, nitrogen doped graphite (NG), graphene oxide, were introduced into the catalytic systems as an active phase, supporting substrate or a multifunctional framework, thereby enhancing the performance. The 2D building blocks not only serve as additional conductivity and structural supported but also promote electron transfer at the interfaces and further enhance the electrocatalytic performance [69]. In 2015, Sasaki reported a novel material of exfoliated NiFe LDH and ultrathin GO as well as reduced rGO via hetero-assemble progress for water splitting reaction (Fig. 5 ) [79]. The heterostructured NiFe LDH@GO hybrid material was demonstrated with remarkable OER efficiency with lower overpotential of 0.23 V as well as super functional HER reaction in 1 mol/L KOH solution. In addition, the water splitting activity was further improved when GO was replaced by rGO with an overpotential downshifted to 0.21 V for OER reaction as well as better HER activity. The reduced oxygen-functional thereby resulted in a more intimate integration and uniform dispersion of NiFe nanosheets on graphene framework, as a consequence, this hierarchical material NiFe@r-GO with enhanced active surface areas, suppressed aggregation and isolation of LDH nanosheets and fast charge transfer was demonstrated to outperform the NiFe@GO for bifunctional activity. Moreover, the researchers also revealed that Fe plays a favorable role on catalytic performance, as increasing the content of Fe in the lattice, more superior catalytic activity can be obtained. A prototype electrochemical cell was successfully constructed by NiFe@rGO exhibiting the potential to electrocatalyze both HER and OER processes which was driven by a single battery of only 1.5 V as shown in Fig. 5(i). Latterly, a hybridized catalyst by anchoring exfoliated NiFe-LDH nanosheet onto defective graphene (DG) was demonstrated [42]. The fabricated material exhibited extraordinary electrocatalytic activity for OER, as the overpotential needed to deliver 10 mA cm−2 current density was determined to be as low as 0.21 V, which was superior to all other non-noble metal catalysts. At the same time, the hybrid structure showed outstanding HER activity with an overpotential of 115 mV by 2 mg cm−2 to deliver 20 mA cm−2 current density. The HER activity keeps almost unchanged for 20000 s at an overpotential of 300 mV. It is noteworthy that there are few researches focusing on LDH-based electrocatalysts exhibiting such preeminent HER activity, even comparable to TMDs and phosphides materials reported to date. The defective sites of graphene were supposed to provide more predominant arching sites for Ni and Fe transition metals, on the other hand, function as the electronic catalytic sites for HER process, resulting in significant excellent activity among the noble-metal free catalysts. In addition, the density-functional theory (DFT) calculation calculation revealed that the hybrid of NiFe-LDHs nanosheets and DG favored the separation and redistribution of holes and electrons at the same time, which promote both of the OER and HER process. The hybrid bifunctional NiFe-LDH@DG with significantly improved activities, advanced kinetics, and enhanced durability provide a smart strategy for tailoring structure and functionality of LDH based catalyst, which would inspire the development of more practical overall water-slitting catalyzer. Moreover, it was found that heteroatom like N, S, P, etc generally could modify the electronic properties and further facilitate the interaction between LDH nanosheets and graphene sheets, which can provide fast charge/electron transport [57,80,81]. The researchers found out that the N on graphene contributed to strong anchoring of Fe, Ni ions for NiFe LDHs, thereby resulting in a strong affinity and uniform dispersion of NiFe-LDHs nanosheets on graphene framework (Fig. 6 ). This hierarchical material possesses intimates interfacial coupling and high surface area as well as fully exposed active sites. As a consequence, the material exhibits significant enhanced OER performance in alkaline medium with high activities, advanced kinetics and long-term durability as the over potential for NiFe-LDH@N-graphene as well as 337 mV to reach the current density of 10 mA cm –2. It is clearly that the importing of N-graphene could significantly accelerate the electrocatalytic activity for OER reaction, however, their advantages for HER reaction are ignored. It was demonstrated that support-free LDH catalysts normally suffer from poor electronic conductivity issues, affecting their long-term stability which further limited their applications. To improve the insufficient electronic conductivity of LDH materials for renewable energy conversion and storage systems, graphdiyne is considered to be the one of the most potential candidates to hybrid with LDH to achieve synergistic enhancement. Graphdiyne, a novel 2D monolayer of sp/sp 2 hybridized carbon based material, is proved to have high electronic conductivity, adjustable electronic structure, structural flexibility and good stability, which has attracted comprehensive interests from the fields of catalysis, electronics, energy conversion/storage [82,83]. In addition, the uniformed porous structure endows it with unique interactions with other materials. As aforementioned, the layered structure of LDH make it easier to introduce a variety of common inorganic anions, organic anions, polyoxometalates and other lamellar structures into its gallery. Due to the flexible and unique structure of both LDH and graphdiyne, the hybridization between these two materials is predicted to have enhanced electrocatalytic properties. In 2018, a bifunctional electrocatalystic material with a sandwiched morphology, comprising of graphdiyne and FeCo-LDH was developed by Li's group [84] firstly as suggested in Fig. 7 . The hybrid material is fabricated by applying in situ growth of graphdiyne onto exfoliation FeCo-LDH nanosheets. To achieve current densities of 10, 100, and 1000 mA cm−2 in 1.0 mol/L medium, this hybridization catalyst presented overpotentials of only 43, 215, and 256 mV to for HER, and 216, 249, and 278 mV for OER, respectively. Both of the experimental and theoretical results suggested that the hybridization of graphdiyne and FeCo-LDH highly improved the charge transport kinetics of the catalyst. Compared to the original FeCo-LDH, the FeCo-LDH@ graphdiyne heterojunction indicate a significant electrocatalytic activity with TOF of 8.44 s−1 at 200 mV for HER and 2.34 s−1 at 250 mV for OER, respectively. Both of experimental and theoretical calculation results proved that the synergistic combination effect significantly facilitated electron/charge transport, augment electrocatalytic active sites, boosting the electrocatalytic efficiency and improving reaction kinetics and stability for OER and HER. It was anticipated such electronic interactions between LDH and graphdiyne at the interface beneficial for the adsorption of *O intermediates, in turn driving the conversion of *O to *OOH with a smaller free energy of 0.54 eV than that of pure GD, thus, enhance the OER performance. In addition, the electrons transferred from adjacent metal atoms in LDH sheets to graphdiyne can afford a driving forth for both the adsorption and desorption of H species, producing outstanding HER activity. In addition, the bifunctional electrocatalyst provided low voltages for overall water splitting as current densities of 10, 100, and 1000 mA cm−2, the voltages were 1.43, 1.46, and 1.49 V respectively. It also exhibited excellent stability and water splitting capability for various cell voltages, even when conducted at a high current density of 1000 mA cm−2 for both the OER (>58 h) and HER (>67 h). A more detailed DFT calculation revealed that the remarkable bifunctional electrocatalytic performance for OER, HER and overall water splitting could be attributed to the synergetic effects of 3d orbitals of TM atoms and C–C triple bonds in graphdiyne [86]. The interaction between graphdiyne and LDH seriously effects the electrocatalytic performance, it has been reported that increasing the hydrophilic of graphdiyne could enhance the chemical and electronic interaction between graphdiyne and LDH. For example, Li et al. [85] design a hybrid material based on ultrathin CoAl-LDH and graphdiyne. The surface of graphdiyne was firstly modified via air-plasma method, turning the surface from intrinsically hydrophobic to superhydrophilic. The obtained superhydrophilic CoAl-LDH@graphdiyne displayed excellent OER activity with an overpotential of 258 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2. The advanced performance can be attributed to the superiorhydrophilic of graphdiyne, which endowed the hybrid material with strong interaction between two sheets and enhanced the enhanced affinity for H2O. Besides the graphene and graphdiyne, g-C3N4, another powerful 2D material, has emerged as a promising alternative molecular electrocatalyst in the field of energy conversion [87,88], CO2 reduction [88] and environmental purification [89]. However, the application of g-C3N4 in electronic water splitting still limited by its poor charge separation. Bhowmik and co-workers designed a hybrid material based on CoFe-LDH and g-C3N4, which exhibited excellent OER, HER and overall water splitting ability in alkaline solution as illustrated in Fig. 2(a) [90]. The material was fabricated by co-precipitation method as the in situ nucleation and growth of 2D CoFe LDH nanosheets onto g-C3N4 without aggregation as the HRTEM measurement demonstrated. As a result, the composition is capable with high conductivity and efficient exposure of active sites, which further increase the electrochemical performances. In addition, a huge amount of high oxidation state of Co3+ is the composite was confirmed by the XPS, which are active site for OER. Moreover, the heteroatoms N not only improved the strong anchoring of LDH sheet on the 2D carbon material but also generated charge separation with highly positive charge density on carbon sheets which favored the adsorption of reactant such as -OH− and H*, that facilitated the OER and HER performance. By optimizing the component, Co0.4Fe0.6-LDH/ g-C3N4 presented excellent OER performance with overpotential as low as 0.28 V to obtain 10 mA cm−2 with 100% faradic efficiency. At the same time, remarkable HER was also achieved. Notable, Co0.4Fe0.6 LDH/g-CNx can act as both cathode and anode material for overall water-splitting in 1 mol/L KOH with a small overpotential of 1.61 V to reach 10 mA cm−2. The combination of LDH and g-C3N4 can conduct excellent electrocatalytic overall water splitting but also photoelectrochemical overall water splitting [65,91–93]. Take the CoMn-LDH@C3N4 for example, by modulating the ratio of g-C3N4 and LDH in the hybrid, the OER and HER activity can be optimized as the small overpotentials of 288 and 406 mV to obtained 10 mA cm−2 current [65]. Overall water splitting with a small overpotential as low as 1.56 V to achieve 10 mA cm –2 is also confirmed. Furthermore, under visible light irradiation (>450 nm), the photoinduced current density of 0.227 mA cm –2 can be obtained for the CoMn-LDH@g-C3N4 hybrid, as the current density of 406 mV at 10 mA cm –2 is achieved, which suggests that the hybridization can serve as an effective photoelectronic catalyst for the overall water-splitting. The cooperation of 2D carbon based material and LDH not only providing a substrate support, but also inhibiting the self-stacking for LDH materials. Moreover, the heterostructure of LDHs and 2D carbon based nanosheets could enhance the conductivity, improve the electron mobility and mass transfer, enhanced OER, HER as well as overall water splitting performance for energy applications. 4.2 Compositing LDHs with TMDs for the water splitting A typical family of graphene-like 2D nanomaterials, layered transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) such as MoS2, WS2, VSe2, and WSe2, with a sandwich like X–M–X configuration (X: S, Se, or Te; M: transition metal element) have been proved to have great potential for applications in energy storage, catalysis, electronics, photonics, etc. [18,94]. This group of materials are featured with (1) large specific surface area which provide efficient contact between active centers and the electrolyte. (2) The adjacent layers in the nanomaterials are coupled by relatively week van der Waals forces. (3) The interlayer space between layers can facilitate fast ion diffusion. (4) The layered configuration can benefit the coupling with other material. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), as a group of well-known TMDs material, has been widely applied in the field of catalysis [94,95], electronic transistors [96], photovoltaics. In the S–Mo–S lattices, the Mo atoms lay in the center positions of the interstices of the S layers. Due to its high anisotropy and unique crystal characterizations, the properties of 2D MoS2 can be tuned via varying dimensions, regulating intercalation, and constructing of multiple heterostructures. Due to plenty of experimental and computational studies, MoS2 has been considered as a powerful catalyst for electrocatalytic HER as is demonstrated in the literature as hydrogen binding energy for MoS2's is located close to the top of the volcano curve [97,98]. More importantly, a plenty of examples have confirmed that MoS2 has promising HER activity in acid media, whereas, its HER kinetics is sluggish in alkaline electrolytes. At the same time, few materials based on MoS2 with OER activity were founded in the literatures which still remains a big challenge. Therefore, heterostructures of super-active OER LDH nanosheets on HER active MoS2 are the promising candidate to improve LDH material's HER activities as well as water splitting performance. One of the typical instances is that NiCo-LDH was vertically coated on MoS2 nanosheets employing microwave hydrothermal reaction progress [99]. The obtained MoS2@NiCo-LDH heterostructure exhibited significant activities for HER catalysis with a remarkable low overpotential of only 78 mV for 10 mA cm –2 and a very low Tafel slope of 76.6 mV s –1 in alkaline medium. In addition, besides the MoS2@NiCo-LDH composites, other combination like MoS2@NiFe-LDH and MoS2@CoFe-LDH hybrids also displayed efficient catalytic performance for HER catalysis than the bare LDHs and MoS2, suggesting the synergistic effect manifest on the MoS2@LDH hybridation. Although LDHs (NiCo-LDH, NiFe-LDH, CoFe-LDH) benefit the adsorption and recombination of OH* intermediate, they are generally inefficient for adsorption of H species, while the importing of MoS2 compensates their incompetence, which drove the enhancement on charge/electron transporting capacity, and electrical conductivity and better HER activity in an alkaline media. It is obvious that the contacting area for the vertical alignment between LDH and MoS2 is quite limited, thought abundant active sites are located at the edge of the MoS2 sheet. If increase the contact surfaces will increase the charge transfer of heterostructures? Focusing on this topic, Hwang et al. [100] reported a strongly coupled NiFe-LDH-MoS2 nanohybrids with mesoporous heterolayered superlattices via the electrostatically driven self-assembly of each exfoliated nanosheets (Figs. 8(e–h) ). Cross-sectional HRTEM images indicated that the stratiform of nanohybrids, where the LDH and MoS2 nanosheet align interstratified face to face. The XPS and DFT calculation of the coupled nanosheets indicated that the interstratification of LDH and MoS2 enhanced a significant charge transfer from LDH nanosheet to MoS2 nanosheet. As a result, the collective hole density in the LDHs improved its OER activity and further enhanced affinity for the OH− reactant, on the other hand, simultaneous accumulation of electron density on MoS2 nanosheet promoted its HER activity due to the amendment of H+ affinity upon the formations of superlattice. Moreover, the interstratification of the two nanosheets effectively promoted the stability and durability when compared with bare LDH nanosheets or MoS2 as negligible degradation was found after 43000s reaction. Compared with NiAl-LDH@MoS2 nanohybrid, NiFe-LDH@MoS2 presented higher OER activity, as the Fe 3d-states located much near the Fermi level than that for Al 2p states, which benefited the hole migration to LDH sheet. These results again proved the emphasis of Fe for LDH's electrocatalytic performance. Unlike aforementioned vertical alignment LDH/MoS2 material, the interstratification of the exfoliated nanosheets play a significant role on both electrocatalytic activity and stability. A meticulous comparison of NiFe-LDH/MoS2 with MoS2@graphene (MoS2@G) and NiFe-LDH@graphene (LDH@G) material was also conducted as shown in Fig. 3 and Figs. 7(i and j) [70]. NiFe-LDH/MoS2 hybridization exhibited much improved electrocatalytic OER and HER activities than the other two materials, MoS2/G and LDH/G superlattices in alkaline environment. Both DFT calculation and experimental results demonstrated that interfacial hybridization effects between different unilamellar nanosheets have profound effects on the resulting superlattices and further determine the ultimately efficient electrocatalytic performance. The above discussed investigations profiled the combination of LDH material and MoS2 had superior potential on water splitting academically. Recent studies profiled that the combination also presented great value in industrial application [101]. Zhang and co-workers [101] studied the NiFe-LDH@MoS x integrated material for OER under artificial industrial electrolysis conditions. In practical industrial electrolysis production, 20%–30% KOH was always chosen to access water splitting at 60–80 °C to further reduce the required voltage. Such harsh condition also put higher rigorous challenge on the tolerance of catalysts (stability and durability). To reach the current density of 100 and 400 mA·cm−2, an overpotential of only 156 and 201 mV under the industrial condition for OER and higher 1.41 V voltage value was required to get 10 mA·cm−2 densities for HER. Notably, 500 continuous cycles with negligible activity decay was determined even at high temperature highlighting the remarkable stability heterostructured composites. The overall water splitting test was also conducted by employing the hybrid material for both anode and cathode under industrial conditions (5 mol/L KOH at 65 °C) and excellent performance and stability were obtained. Therefore, the heterostructured NiFe-LDH@MoS2 material exhibited great prospect of practical application in industrial electrolysis with large-scales, which paved a way to fabricate efficient electrodes for energy conversion technology. Besides MoS2, CoSe, a classic TMDs, has attracted plenty of interests due to its excellent catalytic activity for water splitting such as OER in alkaline and HER in acid media [102,103]. The 2D CoSe (Co0.85Se) nanosheets possess intrinsic abundant active sites, where the OH* species can attach to, that favor the overall water splitting in alkaline solution. It has been proved that Co0.85Se is a promising 2D cocatalyst for practical hydrogen production application [102]. Take full advantages of strong conjunction between the components, Feng et al. designed and synthesized nanohybrid, in which NiFe-LDH with ~10 nm thickness was vertically grown on Co0.85Se nanosheets [104]. The obtained hierarchical hybrid with highly exposed surface area as large as 156 m2 g –1, strong inter-coupling and efficient electrolyte transport channels, presented superior electrocatalytic activity for OER with quiet low overpotential of 150 and 250 mA cm –2 to reach 1.50 and 1.51 V. Outstanding HER performance was also achieved with the obtained hybridization as excellent electrocatalytic activity with a minimal onset potential of –0.24 V was produced. Moreover, the overpotentials at 5 and 10mA cm –2 was obtained as low as –210 and –260 mV, respectively, which is favorably compared with pure Co0.85Se nanosheets and NiFe-LDH. Remarkably, in alkaline medium, overall water splitting applying Co0.85Se@NiFe-LDH as both anode and cathode in a two-electrode system was also fabricated with overpotential of 1.71 V for 20 mA cm –2 and the performance was well comparable with that for the most active combined Pt/C//Ir/C catalysts. Until now a verity of LDH@TMDs nanohybrids have been designed, synthesized and characterized, it includes but not limited to LDH@MoSe2, LDH@ WSe2 and LDH@WS2 [64,105]. It has been proved that the nanohybrids exhibit enhance electrocatalytic actives compared with the pure component. These studies pay a superior way not only for the development of exquisite electrocatalystic materials but also for energy applications in industrial application. 4.3 Compositing LDHs with MXenes for the water splitting Since the discovery in 2011, MXene, a family material with two-dimensional sheet structure comprising of transition metal carbides (TMCs), nitrides (TMNs), and carbonitrides (TMCNs) has emerged as promising active materials for energy storage and conversion [106,107]. Until now, more than 70 different compositions ((e.g., Ti2C, Ti3C2, Ti3CN, Nb2C, Mo2C and V2C, etc.) belonging to this family have been predicted and only about twenty MXenes materials have been successfully synthesized and characterized [108]. Such materials with general formula of M n+1AX n are manufactured by selectively etching of layered M n+1AX n phase by etching agent (M presents transition metals like Ti, Mo, etc, A presents element from group 13 and 14, e.g., Al. and X presents C and/or N element, n = 1, 2, or 3). The outstanding metallic conductivity, abundant anchoring/active points and easily scaled up endowed their application in the field of catalysis research, especially in electro- and photoelectrocatalysis. The experimental results have elucidated that MXenes (Mo2CT x and Ti2CT x ) possess modest HER activity [109–111]. Unlike 2D MoS2 material whose active sites mainly restricted to the edge of the sheet, the active sites were determined to be dominant on the MXenes' basal planes [96,98,112]. Plenty of theoretical calculation has indicated that many MXenes are expected to possess efficient OER [113], HER [27], ORR [28], CO2RR [114] and nitrogen reduction (N2RR) activities [115]. The layered character and diverse T x groups on the surface of MXenes endows the material with a variety of tunability in their properties, hence, high compatibility with a secondary material to construct hybridization for electrocatalytic applications [116]. Especially, the abundant and negatively charged T x groups facilitated the assemble positive charged Brucite-like metal layer, thus realizing unique properties as well as improved performance. Therefore, an electrocatalytically active LDH coupling with a highly conducting MXenes could be an effective medium for achieving a promising functional electrocatalysis for OER, HER and bifunctional water splitting [66,68,117–122]. Recently, integration of MXenes with FeNi-LDH for electrocatalytic OER was reported by Qiu et al. [66] in which a hierarchical FeNi-LDH/Ti3C2 architecture with 80 wt% FeNi-LDHs was determined. The FeNi-LDH grow vertically on the top of MXene support by ionic hetero-assembly between positively charged FeNi-LDH nanosheets and Ti3C2, promoting the electrocatalystic surface area, electron conductivity and mass adsorption and transporting. High-resolution XPS analysis (Figs. 9(b) and (c) ) was conducted to determine the strong interfacial and synergy interaction between FeNi-LDH nanosheet and Ti3C2 sheets, where ±0.5–0.6 eV shift of the Ni and Fe 2p peaks in XPS spectra was monitored as compared with pure LHDs. The lowest charge-transfer impedance was found to be 5.1 Ω for FeNi-LDH/Ti3C2-MXene heterostructure, while that for FeNi-LDH atop GO and pure FeNi-LDH material were found to be 24.7 Ω and 10.0 Ω respectively, which significantly reduced the potential energy barrier for current transporting (Fig. 8(e)). Beneficially, the FeNi-LDH/Ti3C2-MXene hybrid material exhibited superb OER activity in alkaline medium with much lower overpotential of 0.298 V at 10 mA cm−2. A fellow-up investigation on the integrated FeNi-LDH with Ti3C2T x was conducted by the same group as encouraged by the outstanding HER and OER properties [68]. The unique design of FeNi-LDH/MXene electrode exhibits high conductivity and excellent electrocatalytic overall water-splitting ability with high current density due to the cooperative effect between LDH and MXene nanosheets. The collaborating material accelerated the mass/charge transport across the heterointerfaces, at the same time, facilitated redox process of NiFe-LDH nanosheets for OER, rendered the exposure of more active sites and promoted the Volmer step for HER by enhancing the water adsorption/activation on the MXene side. The synergytic effect enabled the hierarchical FeNi-LDH/MXene architecture to outperform their individual component for both HER and OER in 1.0 mol/L KOH, promoting the hybridization more attractive for practical application. As a result, the NiFe-LDH/MXene displayed a larger but significantly improved ηj = 10 (249 mV) compared to Pt/C (127 mV), and its activity can transcend Pt/C performance when the overpotential was increased to 0.665 V for HER in 1.0 mol/L KOH solution. The Ni2+ species in NiFe-LDHs materials are known capable of adsorbing and fast distortion water molecules, on this basis, the combination of hydrophilic MXene further improved the water adsorption, electrode wetting and promoted the coverage of Hads at the material surfaces. XPS analysis demonstrated that the d-band center of Ni/Fe species shifted to higher energy position and caused the anti-bonding states between adsorbed O* intermediates and LDH less occupied, thereby promoting O*-LDH binding and the redox activity of OER, as a result, superior OER property was achieved with the NiFe-LDH@MXene hybridization. Moreover, the LDH@ MXene hybrids can be converted to phosphosulfies, processing further to form bifunctional materials. For instance, Du et al. [118] reported a facial self-assembled FeNi-LDH/MXenes nanohybrids converted to 2D bimetallic NiFePS3/MXene hybridization through a solid-state annealing approach with phosphorus. The obtained NiFePS3/MXene hybridization possessed a unique nanomosaic morphology with abundant active sites and high electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) due to the lattice stress. Notably, the catalytic performance was modulated depending on the initial ratio of Ni-Fe in LDH precursor. When the initial ratio of Ni:Fe was 7:3, the achieved NiFe-PS3/MXene hybridation required an overpotential of 282 mV with Tafel slope of 36.5 mV dec−1 at 10 mA cm−2 for OER. While, when the ratio of Ni:Fe is 9:1, Ni0.9Fe0.1PS3/Ti3C2T x was determined to be most proficient for HER in alkaline medium. Moreover, for electrocataltytic overall water splitting, the combination of Ni0.7Fe0.3PS3/ MXene||Ni0.9Fe0.1PS3/MXene electrode required only 1.65 V to deliver 10 mA·cm−2 current density, which obviously outperformed the standard IrO2||Pt/C electrocatalyst (1.71 V). The nanohybrid material in this work demonstrated the chemical versatility played an essential role in modulating the electronic activity and energy conversion. This work offers a general and promising strategy for rotational design of efficient electrocatalytic material for OER, HER as well as overall water splitting reaction depending on hybridation of LDH and MXenes. The above argument suggested that the chemical versatility played a significant role on the catalytic performance. On the other hand, Ti3C2 is considered as one of the most popular MXene nanomaterials, which was verified to exhibit novel optical and plasmonic properties. To invested the plasmonic effect of Ti3C2 on the hybridation, a hybrid system based on N-doped Ti3C2 (N10TC) MXene and NiFe-LDH nanosheets was developed (namely NiFe-LDH/N10TC) and the plasmonic effect on electrocatalytic performance was further invested. A typical board plasmon absorption band located in the visible to near-infrared (NIR) region of UV-vis spectrum was discovered and suggesting a strong plasmonic interaction between nanosheets for the hybrid NiFe-LDH/N10TC material. A much higher current density and lower overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cm –2 was disclosed for the obtained catalyst. Moreover, an additional light irradiation enabled an additional (photogenerated) hot carriers of plasmonic N10TC, which further promoted the OER activity, as a result, at 100 mA cm –2, a down shift for the overpotential from 278 to 264 mV for OER and a little higher current density and smaller onset overpotential for HER was achieved. Ti based MXene is the mostly used in complexing with LDH to fabric nanosheets, among the family of MXene, V-based Mxene has gained extensive interests due to its outstanding electrical conductivity, relatively chemically stable and practical synthesizability and applicability for batteries [119,123,124]. Chen and co-workers [123] has developed a system of V2C MXene synergistically coupling FeNi LDH nanosheets for boosting OER and ORR application. On the one hand, the strong electronic interaction between the interface promoted charge transfer and enhanced the reaction kinetic for OER in KOH solution, on the other hand, the down shift of Fe/Ni sheet accelerated the OER process. Additional, novel ORR activities with an onset potential of 0.89 V and a higher half-wave potential of 0.8 V (Fig. 8(h)) was verified in 1.0 mol/L KOH solution. Based on the outstanding overall oxygen electrocatalysis performance with a lower ΔE value ~0.673 V comparing with a Pt/C combining RuO2 commercial catalyst (0.682 V), a liquid rechargeable Zn-air battery driven by nanohybrid material as the air cathode was constructed to value its feasibility in practical energy devices. The obtained Zn-air battery displayed a higher power density as well as better stability when co Pt/C||RuO2 based battery (Figs. 8(i) and 8(j)), fully demonstrates the hybrids' feasible application for promoted energy storage and conversion. A variety of hybrid based on MXene and LDH has been proved not only feasible for water splitting but also for other formal energy storage, like photoelectron water splitting, high-performance or asymmetric supercapacitor. This kind of hybrids supply a promising strategy to achieve high performance and inexpensive energy storage devices. 4.4 Other 2D materials hybrid with LDH for water splitting In addition to these reported 2D materials which can hybrid with LDH, other 2D material like MOF nanosheets [125,126], perovskite oxide [127–129] or another LDH sheet [130] are also fabricated and employed for energy conversion application. For example, a strong coupled conductive MOF (cMOF) and NiFeCo-LDH nanocomposite was demonstrated as an excellent electrocatalyst for water oxidation under alkaline conditions [131]. The interface heterojunctions between LDH and MOF were demonstrated to strongly improve the electrical and chemical structures, the catalytic activity of the OER and stability of NiFeCo-LDH. In addition, a unique heteroarray configuration was achieved during hydrothermal conditions (cMOF/LDH-48) with 48 h. The structure with 10 nm-thick nanolayer of cMOF on the outer wall of the LDH was proved to be an intermediate state as an internal template sacrifice process as indicated in Fig. 10 . The heterostructure inherited and integrated merits from both outer wall of cMOF and intercore of NiFeCo LDH components, that was, hierarchical porous structure with a large specific surface area (220 m2 g−1), good electrical conductivity as well as abundant surface active sites for electronic water oxidation. The outstanding chemical and chemical structure of cMOF/LDH-48 conduced remarkable OER activity with ultrasmall overpotentials of 0.216 and 0.227 mV at 50 and 100 mA cm−2, which outperformed many previously reported noble-metal-free catalysts (Fig. 10). Recently, Yang and co-workers [130] fabricated a heterostructure with two different layer of LDH materials where a layer of CoFe-LDH grow on NiFe-LDH nanosheets via a facile hydrothermal and electrodeposition method. Notably, benefiting from the strong electronic interaction at the heterostructures, a fast charge transfer at the interface and optimizing binding energies of the reaction intermediates was achieved, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic efficiency and accelerating the reaction kinetics. Additionally, the hybrid architectures provided abundant active sites which could facilitated ion diffusion (OH*) and gas release (H2 and O2). The developed CoFe-LDH@NiFe-LDH hybrid catalyst exhibited remarkable activities and stabilities for both OER and HER. Moreover, a voltage of 1.59 V at 10 mA cm−2 by applying CoFe-LDH@NiFe-LDH as both cathode and anode, which is among the top of state-of-the-art earth abundant catalysts . 4.5 Multiple nanohybrids based on LDH for water splitting The example we discussed above mainly focus on the habitation of binary material in which LDH combined with graphene or MXene materials, hybrid LDH nanostructures based on ternary materials can be also designed for robust and more competent electrode materials. For example, Yu's group facilely fabric a multilayer-stacked hybrid structure of ternary system based on LDH, comprising with MoS2 and graphene nanosheets as shown in Fig. 11 . The graphene sheets, MoS2 nanosheets, and FeCoNi(OH) x or FeCoNiP x nanosheets successively vertically stacked on carbon fibers (CFs) electro via thermal chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and consequently electrodeposition progress. The DFT calculation indicated an obvious forbidden band for FeCoNi(OH) X , which drove barely electron transfer, while the band gap for the hybridization of MoS2/FeCoNi(OH) X was almost negligible, which was highly favorable to charge transfer, at the same time vertical graphene sheets acts as a good substrates of the active materials due to its preeminent conductivity. The catalyst exhibits excellent OER, HER as well as overall water splitting performance in 1 mol/L KOH solution ascribing to the synergy effect. In situ co-assembly of NiFe-LDH nanosheets and WSe2 nanosheets together on a N,S-co-doped graphene sheet was constructed by a facile hydrothermal approach and followed by an electrostatic self-assembly progress [132]. The resulted monohybrid architecture maximizes synergistic effects among the individual 2D nanosheets for promoting overall water splitting and supercapacitor application. Modifying the BiVO4 films with efficient OER LDH catalysts is one of the most common approaches to improve the water oxidation catalysts, however, it has been proved that LDHs decorated BiVO4 photoanodes for photoelectrochemical water splitting only show barely satisfied performances. The involvement of rGOs sheet could facilitate the electron deposition of LDH on BiVO4 surface, on the other hand the rGO sheets is capable of quickly abstract the photogenerated holes and inhibiting the electron-hole recombination, as a result, the ternary components show remarkable electrochemical and/or photoelectrochemical water splitting capability [133–135]. 5 Potential 2D materials for modulating LDHs for water splitting 2D materials have been emerged as as a new material platform for fundamental studies due to their unique physical characteristics, such as magnetism, superconductivity and charge density waves. Although most efforts have been focused on graphenes, Mxenes, LDHs, TMDs, other 2D materials like metal halide-based materials (e.g. BiI3, CdI2 and CrI3), 2D carbon-metal sheets, 2D covalent organic frameworks (COFs) and 2D metals, have attracted considerable considerations for their extraordinary structural and electronic properties. For example, Yang et al. [136] developed a constructing process to develop freestanding Sb thin nanosheets via exfoliation of bulk Sb powder in IPA solution (Fig. 12(a) ). The unique ultrathin Sb nanosheets can compose uniformed hybridization sheets with graphene with tunable density. By take full advantages of the high density of Sb nanosheets, the density of hybrid electrode films can be significantly enhanced. More importantly, a very high reversible volumetric capacity of 1226 mAh cm−3@0.1 mA cm−2was achieved for the hybrid materials. It is worth noting that pure Sb nanosheets possess preeminent electrocatalytic performance in terms of HER, OER and ORR and CO2 reduction. Though the hybridization of Sb nanosheets and LDH hasn't been reported, we could expect that the high density of Sb nanosheets and preeminent electrocatalytic properties could endow Sb@LDH hybridization with excellent water splitting performance. 2D COFs has attracted considerable attentions during the past decades, thought the investigations for COFs were still in the infancy, the remarkable high crystallinity, large surface area, unique molecular architecture and tunable pore size has promoted COFs for a potential electrocatalysts. COFs as an ambitious material are a new development in searching for competent and cost-effective electrocatalysts for water splitting reactions. For instance, Bhunia and co-workers designed and synthesized metal-free 2D COFs based electrocatalyst for electrocatalytic HER, which exhibited a significant small onset overpotential of ≈0.05 V. Most 2D COFs are equipped with π-conjugated structures, which benefit the charge or electron transport. On the other hand, π–π interaction could facilitate the assembling the 2D COFs with other sheet materials such like LDHs to form hybridizations. From both of synthetic strategy and further energy application, the hybridization of COFs and LDHs provide us with new possibilities. 6 Remarks and perspectives Although many researches have been verified for the hybridization of LDH to achieve promoted performance, enhanced activity and long-term stability for water splitting system. Nevertheless, a huge gap between laboratorial work and commercial applications still exits and need to be fulfilled. First of all, there is a lack of a facilely method to synthesize high-quality and large-scale composites with controllable size, composition, and architecture. Secondly, the mutual effects between the LDH sheet and the hybrid species are rather complicated and deeper fundamental insight into the precisely structural manipulating is still a challenge. Thirdly, current studies are mainly applying rigid support like Ni foam/mesh or carbon close, which actually barely used in real industrial electrolysis technique, more effort may be required to embed LDHs onto polymer/anion electrolyte membranes. Therefore, robust structural designs and facially constructing strategies and advanced electrode device technique should be developed to fabricate hybrid LDH catalysts that can be potentially for practical applications. All of the above examples indicated LDH as a favorable platform for other 2D materials, besides, they could also conduct as platform for the stabilization of single-atom catalysts (SACs) [138,139]. Recently, SACs, which involves isolated metal atoms individually dispersed on the supports, has drawn extensive attentions for achieving high atom utilization efficiency, high activity and selectivity in electrocatalysis [140–155]. The combination of LDHs and SACs was proved to be favorable for water splitting, we truly believe that the integration of SACs supported LDH and 2D material will provide new directions in developing high activity and cost effective electrocatalyst for overall water splitting [156–158]. Besides, other 2D materials like metal halide-based materials, 2D carbon-metal sheets, 2D COFs and 2D metals also provide new opportunities in modulating LDHs materials due to their unique chemical and electronic properties. Finally, theoretical techniques have provided insights into the catalytic mechanisms, including electronic properties, identification of active sites, energy transfer adsorption and distortion of intermediates at the atomic and molecular levels. 7 Conclusions Enhancing the electronic conductivity and maximizing the exposed active sites of LDHs play a critical role in boosting the overall water splitting performance. Hybridizing with other 2D materials could induce better electrical conductivity and abundant catalytically active sites, and thereby has been intensively explored in recent years. This review critically examines the progress in the fabrication of hierarchical hybrid nanostructure consisting of LDHs and other 2D materials with emphasis on the carbon-based materials, TMDs, Mxenes, etc. and their electrocatalytic applications (Table 1 ). By carefully exploring the advances of 2D materials modulating LDH hybrids for water splitting reactions, we can conclude the merits as follows: (1) The hybridization can prevent the restacking of both materials which can maintain its novel activities and long-term stabilities. (2) The introduction of 2D materials highly improves the intrinsic conductivity of the LDH catalysts. (3) Abundant heterogeneous interfaces could afford more active sites exposure, highly efficient electron transfer, optimized electron distribution and multiple synergistic effects. The LDH-based hybrids have opened a new horizon for developing high activity and cost effective electrocatalyst for overall water splitting. This review will inspire the development of a new branch of advanced electrocatalyst for material science and energy application. References 1 J. Greeley T.F. Jaramillo J. Bonde I.B. coredata.dc:description: Exploring highly efficient electrochemical water splitting catalysts has recently attracted extensive research interest from both fundamental researches and practical applications. Transition metal-based layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have been proved to be one of the most efficient materials for oxygen evolution reaction (OER), however, still suffered from low conductivity and sluggish kinetics for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which largely inhibited the overall water splitting efficiency. To address this dilemma, enormous approaches including doping regulation, intercalation tuning and defect engineering are therefore rationally designed and developed. Herein, we focus on the recent exciting progress of LDHs hybridization with other two-dimensional (2D) materials for water splitting reactions, not barely for enhancing OER efficiency but also for boosting HER activity. Particularly, the structural features, morphologies, charge transfer and synergistic effects for the heterostructure/heterointerface that influence the electrocatalytic performance are discussed in details. The hybrid 2D building blocks not only serve as additional conductivity and structural supported but also promote electron transfer at the interfaces and further enhance the electrocatalytic performance. The construction and application of the nanohybrid materials will guide a new direction in developing multifunctional materials based on LDHs, which will contribute to energy conversion and storage.

coredata.dc:title: 2D materials modulating layered double hydroxides for electrocatalytic water splitting
